bestBHT.bht: In this account, the remarkable wonders and signs that God performed in Egypt and at the Red Sea are emphasized as demonstrations of His power and deliverance. Stephen's deep admiration and love for God make any accusation of blasphemy against him utterly unfounded. This marks a significant epoch in the history of God's chosen people, where they are united under Moses' leadership in the wilderness. It serves as a compelling reminder of God's miraculous interventions and His unwavering faithfulness in rescuing His people from oppression.

Albert Barnes: Wonders and signs - Miracles, and remarkable interpositions of God.
In the land of Egypt - By the ten plagues.
In the Red sea - Dividing it, and conducting the Israelites in safety, and overthrowing the Egyptians.
Philip Schaff: Stephen shows how utterly absurd was any charge brought against him of blasphemy against one whom he admired with so ungrudging an admiration, and loved with so deep a love.

In the first epoch, the origin of the chosen people is recounted, and how the Lord God came to choose them out of all the tribes of the earth; but in it they never became more than a large family of wandering shepherds.

The third and the greatest epoch in the history of the chosen people commences in the wilderness. The children of Israel, now free and strong, are united under the supreme command of that Moses whom they had so repeatedly refused to obey.
John Gill: He brought them out,.... Of Egypt, and delivered them from all their oppressions in it.
...by dividing the waters of it, so that the people of Israel went through it as on dry ground, which Pharaoh and his army attempting to do, were drowned.
This exactly agrees with what has been before observed on Acts 7:23 from the Jewish writings, that Moses was forty years in Pharaoh's court, forty years in Midian, and forty years in the wilderness.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Acts 7:36, the commentator highlights the wonders and signs that God performed in the land of Egypt and in the Red Sea as a testament to His power and deliverance. Stephen's admiration and love for God is evident as he refutes the charge of blasphemy against him. The commentator further explains that this verse is part of the third and greatest epoch in the history of the chosen people, where the Israelites, now free and strong, are united under the leadership of Moses in the wilderness. This verse serves as a reminder of God's miraculous interventions and His faithfulness in delivering His people from oppression.

In this passage, the wonders and signs performed by God in Egypt and in the Red Sea are highlighted as a demonstration of His power and deliverance. The deep admiration and love for God expressed by Stephen make any charge of blasphemy against him seem absurd. This passage marks the beginning of a significant epoch in the history of God's chosen people, where they are united under the leadership of Moses in the wilderness. It serves as a powerful reminder of God's miraculous interventions and His faithfulness in delivering His people from oppression.
